TODAY IN HISTORY, via @Investopedia $DJIA 
May 26, 1896 
  
On this day in 1896, the Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) was first published, listing 12 companies as its members. 
  
The DJIA was the idea of Charles Dow and Edward Jones, who founded Dow Jones & Co., a financial news organization, in 1882. The company provided subscribers with a newsletter that gave readers insights into how the market was doing that day, listing nine stocks in the shipping and railroad industries. 
  
Eventually Dow and Jones expanded the average to include the biggest stocks in the market, and used a simple addition and division formula that created 40.95 as the first DJIA.

TODAY IN HISTORY, via @Investopedia $AOL 
May 24, 1985 
  
On this day in 1985, online services company Quantum Computer Services was launched. It later became known as America Online (AOL). 
  
Political science major Steve Case was vice president of marketing for the firm, which aimed to provide an online bulletin board for owners of Commodore computers.  
  
In 1991, Quantum changed its name and Case became CEO. Two years later AOL introduced its own email addresses, a Windows version, and access to the entire internet for its users. 
  
AOL became an internet powerhouse and in 2000 merged with Time Warner, the biggest corporate deal in history at that time. Eventually, the companies split up, and with business fading, AOL was bought by Verizon in 2015. Verizon sold it to Apollo Global Management in 2021.  
  
Source: Time 
Steve Case and Time Warner CEO Gerald Levin 
Erik Freeland / Getty Images

Here are all my $META trades month-to-date in May. Only opts, mostly spreads. All are as small as they can be: no order was for more than a single contract! The risk is also only moderate: the spreads balance and allocate risk well.

TODAY IN HISTORY, via @Investopedia $ORCL 
May 23, 1995 
  
On this day in 1995, Sun Microsystems introduced Java, a programming language designed to run on any platform. 
  
Sun began work on the project in 1991, calling it Oak. However, when the company tried to register the name, it had already been taken. Eventually, Sun settled on Java and used a modernized drawing of a cup of coffee as its logo. It also adapted the slogan, “Write Once, Run Anywhere.” 
  
Following the announcement, Netscape announced that it would license Java, releasing the first Java-enabled version of the Netscape Navigator browser. 
  
Billions Using Java 
Ten years later, Sun estimated that there were more than 4.5 million Java developers, 2.5 billion Java-enabled devices, and 1 billion Java-based smartcards. 
  
In 2009, Oracle bought Sun Microsystems for $7.4 billion. 
  
Source: Oracle; Getty Images

If you bet in both directions at once, you can only be wrong once, not twice. 😉 If that sounds crazy, $STUDY Mates, well, then you need to think about how options credit spreads work. 
 
With credit spreads, you get paid now for accepting a known limited risk. Well, okay! So, if you do one spread in each direction, maybe they'll both be right. Maybe one will bite you. But they won't both be wrong! It's a sweet idea. 
 
In options trading, this has a name: an iron condor. Check it out! 
 
#stop_losing_all_the_time

TODAY IN HISTORY, via @Investopedia $DOW 
May 18, 1897 
  
On this day in 1897, Herbert Henry Dow founded the Dow Chemical Company in Midland, Mich. 
  
An electrochemical pioneer, Dow failed at his first two attempts to launch his own business, and the new company struggled at first, with critics nicknaming him “Crazy Dow.” 
  
A year later, Dow began its first commercial-scale production of bleach. The firm later exited that market and began making chemicals for the agricultural, pharmaceutical, water purification, energy, and automotive industries. Its move into plastics led to the creation of a kitchen staple, Saran Wrap. 
  
Dow merged with DuPont in 2015, separated four years later, and was then listed in the Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA). 
  
Source: Dow

TODAY IN HISTORY, via @Investopedia $STUDY 
May 16, 1792 
  
One of the most important events in the history of financial markets occurred on this day in 1792. 
  
That was when 24 stockbrokers and merchants on Wall Street in New York met under a buttonwood tree and signed the landmark Buttonwood Agreement to create a stock exchange. The pact called for participants to deal only with each other, and to charge clients 0.25% commission on trades.  
  
The Buttonwood Agreement formed the foundation of what would become the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE), and began with three government bonds and two bank stocks being traded. 
 
Museum of American Finance

TODAY IN HISTORY, via @Investopedia 
May 14, 1984 
  
Mark Zuckerberg, the founder and CEO of Meta Platforms (formerly Facebook), was born in White Plains, NY on this day in 1984. Zuckerberg founded and launched Facebook in early 2004 as a sophomore at Harvard University. The platform, initially named “Thefacebook,” first launched on February 4, 2004. Initially limited to Harvard and the surrounding area, the platform grew in popularity, and Zuckerberg dropped out of Harvard to focus on the new business. Today, Facebook parent Meta Platforms is one of the most valuable companies in the world by market capitalization.

TODAY IN HISTORY, via @Investopedia $MAT 
May 13, 1999 
  
On this day in 1999, Mattel made one of the worst corporate deals in modern history, buying the educational software company The Learning Co. for $3.5 billion. 
  
Mattel had pursued The Learning Co. as a way to expand beyond its traditional toy business. However, the combination was a flop, and by the end of the year Mattel had taken $342 million in restructuring charges related to the acquisition. 
  
Just 16 months after buying it, Mattel sold The Learning Co. to a subsidiary of Gores Technology Group for virtually nothing. It received no cash up front, but would get a percentage of any future profits. 
  
The sale was part of a larger restructuring at Mattel aimed at realigning the company’s finances. That also included job cuts and the slashing of Mattel’s quarterly dividend.  
  
Source: CNN Money 
Mattel

TODAY IN HISTORY, via @Investopedia $BRK.B 
May 10, 1965 
  
On this day in 1965, Warren Buffett took control of Berkshire Hathaway. 
  
At the time, Berkshire was a struggling New England textile manufacturer, and in 1964 Buffett had agreed to sell off his 7% stake in the firm to its then-president Seabury Stanton for $11.50 per share. However, Stanton changed the offer to $11.375 per share, and an angry Buffett decided instead to buy up more shares. By the next year, he owned 40% of the company, enough to oust Stanton and take charge. 
  
Buffett then began to build Berkshire into a massive conglomerate, which today has a market capitalization of $700 billion. Buffett’s success at Berkshire made him arguably the most famous investor of all time, and helped him become one the richest people in the world.  
  
Source: Berkshire Hathaway

TODAY IN HISTORY, via @Investopedia $GM 
April 29, 2004 
 
On this day in 2004, America’s oldest automobile brand produced its last car. 
 
Oldsmobile, founded by Ransom Olds in 1897, rolled its final vehicle off the assembly line at its Lansing, Mich. plant, which had been making cars for more than a century. 
 
Oldsmobile became part of General Motors in 1908, and was seen as a mid-priced brand in GM’s lineup. However, sales started to slump in the late 1980s, and in 2000 GM announced it would end Oldsmobile production. 
 
The final car made was a black cherry red Alero. 
 
Source: CNN 
Tim Boyle / Getty Images

TODAY IN HISTORY, via @Investopedia $DD 
April 27, 1896 
  
Wallace Carothers, the inventor of nylon, was born on this day in 1896 in Burlington, Iowa. 
  
Carothers was a chemist who joined DuPont in 1928 and began working on synthetic products. With tensions growing between the U.S. and Japan in the 1930s, DuPont tasked Carothers and his team to come up with a substitute for hard-to-get silk. The product they created at DuPont was called nylon, and patented it the next year. 
  
Dubbed the “miracle fiber,” nylon’s popularity grew following World War II, driven by demand for its use in women’s stockings. Nylon has also been used in a wide range of other products, including clothing, parachutes, and even the flag astronaut Neil Armstrong planted on the moon. 
  
Source: American Chemical Society 
Getty Images

TODAY IN HISTORY, via @Investopedia $IBM 
April 19, 1895 
  
On this day in 1895, the Railroad Gazette published the first description for a business audience of a new data-processing device invented by engineer Herman Hollerith. 
  
Called an electric tabulating machine, it employed punch cards with holes in them to hold the information. The machine used electrical signals to read, count and sort the cards.  
  
Hollerith incorporated this “batch processing” method in his company called Computing-Tabulating-Recording Company. It later was renamed International Business Machines, or IBM.  
  
Source: Library of Congress, IBM 
Smithsonian Institution

TODAY IN HISTORY, via @Investopedia $BAC 
April 18, 1906 
  
On this day in 1906, a devastating earthquake struck Northern California, destroying much of the city of San Francisco.  
  
The ensuing fire burned down the large banks, making them inaccessible. 
However, A.P. Giannini, the founder of the small Bank of Italy in the city’s North Beach section, was able to recover $80,000 worth of coins.  
  
He used the money to set up a makeshift bank on the San Francisco wharf, lending out money to struggling residents “on a handshake.” His efforts were key to helping the city recover from the disaster. 
  
Giannini’s Bank of Italy grew, and in 1930 became the Bank of America, the name it continues to have today, along with the same national bank charter number as his old bank. 
  
Source: Office of the Comptroller of the Currency 
Historical / Getty Images

April 15, 1955 
  
On this day in 1955, a milkshake machine salesman named Ray Kroc opened the first McDonald's restaurant in Des Plaines, Illinois. Kroc believed he could succeed by transferring assembly line methods to food preparation, and essentially created the fast-food industry in America. On its first day, the restaurant made $366 selling 15-cent burgers and 10-cent French fries. Boosted by the post-World War II boom that saw millions traveling by car and needing a quick meal, McDonald's quickly grew, eventually dominating the U.S. fast-food market and becoming an iconic global brand. Today, there are some 39,000 McDonald's restaurants in more than 100 countries, with their ubiquitous golden arches proclaiming billions served.  
    
Source: McDonald's

TODAY IN HISTORY, via @Investopedia $GOOG 
April 13, 2007 
 
On this day in 2007, Google (now Alphabet) outbid Yahoo and Microsoft to purchase digital marketing services provider DoubleClick from private equity firm Hellman & Friedman. 
 
The $3.1 billion pricetag was almost thrice what Hellman & Friedman paid when it took DoubleClick private in 2005. 
 
Google's move was aimed at boosting its display advertising, where it had trailed Yahoo. Google CEO Eric Schmidt noted DoubleClick’s technology was widely adopted by leading advertisers, publishers and agencies. He said combining the two companies will accelerate Google’s growth in the display ad space. 
 
Analysts had anticipated DoubleClick would sell for about $2 billion, but Schmidt defended the higher cost. He explained that after doing a detailed financial analysis, Google decided it could afford to pay more, and that it would be a good deal for the company and its shareholders. 
 
Source: CNN Money 
Erik Freeland / Getty Images

TODAY IN HISTORY, via @Investopedia $YHOO 
April 12, 1996 
  
On this day in 1996, Yahoo began publicly trading on the Nasdaq. 
 
Shares of the internet directory service sold for $13 in its IPO. However, the shares opened at $24.50 and rose as high as $43 before closing at $33. The 154% jump in price was the third-highest one-day increase in history at the time, and gave Yahoo a market cap near $1 b. 
 
Yahoo IPOed just two years after the David Filo and Jerry Yang, two Stanford electrical-engineering graduate students, formed the company. It grew to be a powerful online force, offering search, email, news, and more. However, competition from Google (now Alphabet) and some poor business decisions led to its decline. Yahoo’s core assets were sold to Verizon in 2017, becoming part of subsidiary Oath, with the rest rebranded to Altaba. In 2021, Verizon sold its interest in Yahoo to Apollo Global Management. 
 
Source: NYT, Apollo 
David Filo and Jerry Yang 
Eric Sander / Getty Images

TODAY IN HISTORY, via @Investopedia $CCF  
March 31, 1996 
  
On this day in 1996, the largest U.S. bank at the time was formed as Chase Manhattan Corporation and Chemical Banking Corporation completed their $10 billion merger. 
  
The new firm kept what was the more recognizable Chase Manhattan name, even though Chemical was the larger partner. Chase Manhattan had almost $300 billion in assets, surpassing the previous largest bank, Citicorp. 
  
Another merger four years later brought Chase Manhattan and JP Morgan together, creating JPMorgan Chase. In 2004, JPMorgan Chase added Bank One to its portfolio. 
  
During the 2007-2008 financial crisis, the company purchased Washington Mutual after it collapsed in the biggest bank failure in U.S. history. At that time, JPMorgan Chase also bought another struggling financial firm, Bear Stearns. 
  
Today, JPMorgan Chase is the country’s biggest bank, with a market capitalization of about $380 billion.

TODAY IN HISTORY, via @Investopedia $TXN  
February 6, 1958 
  
On this day in 1958, Texas Instruments filed for a patent for the first integrated circuit, a revolutionary breakthrough in the tech industry. 
  
The company’s Jack Kilby was working on a way to make another key invention, the transistor, even smaller. In the summer of 1957, he created the “Solid Circuit” made out of silicon and was the size of a pencil point.  
  
However, while the Texas Instrument patent was being considered, Robert Noyce of startup Fairchild Semiconductor came up with a better way to connect the parts, calling them “unitary circuits.” Noyce also applied for a patent, providing very specific details in an effort to avoid infringing on Kilby’s version.  
  
That worked, because in April 1961, Noyce was granted a patent while Kilby and Texas Instruments still waited.  
  
In the end, both men have been acknowledged as having independently conceived the idea. 
  
Source: PBS

TODAY IN HISTORY, via @Investopedia $STUDY  
January 29, 1997 
  
On this day in 1997, the U.S. Federal Reserve offered its first treasury inflation-protected security, or TIPS. TIPS are treasury bonds tied to the Consumer Price Index or CPI, a key measure of inflation. This means that the bond’s value will keep pace with inflation, making it a safe investment when you expect inflation to be high. As a tradeoff for this lower risk, TIPS offer a lower yield than normal Treasury bonds of an equivalent duration. This creates a way to measure bond-buyers’ inflation expectations, because TIPS yields will fall if investors think inflation will be high, as they are willing to sacrifice more yield for inflation protection. This difference in yields is known as the “TIPS spread.”  
Getty Images

On this day in 1914, automobile pioneer Henry Ford stunned workers at Ford’s Highland Park, Mich. factory by announcing he was more than doubling their pay. Ford said employees would get $5 an hour for an eight-hour shift, up from the previous $2.34 for a nine-hour workday.

TODAY IN HISTORY. via @Investopedia $GT 
December 29, 1800 
 
On this day in 1800, Charles Goodyear was born in New Haven, CT. 
 
Goodyear was fascinated by the possibility of creating rubber products for industrial use. He spent years attempting to perfect a method that would prevent it from melting in high heat. While working at the Eagle India Rubber Company, he combined rubber and sulfur on a hot stove and found it not only didn’t melt, it actually hardened. 
 
It took several more years for Goodyear to perfect his formula. In 1844 he patented his process. He called it vulcanization after Vulcan, the Roman god of fire. 
 
Sadly for Goodyear, he spent much of the fortune he made on his invention fighting patent infringement cases. He died $200,000 in debt in 1860. The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company was named in his honor. Sports fans today are reminded of his work when the Goodyear Blimp passes over stadiums around the country. 
Source: CT History 
Tom Szczerbowski/Getty Images

TODAY IN HISTORY, via @Investopedia $SIEB 
December 28, 1967 
 
On this day in 1967, Muriel Siebert became the first woman to be a member of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE). 
 
Known as “The First Woman of Finance,” Siebert worked for three brokerage firms before deciding to buy a seat on the exchange. The first nine men she asked to sponsor her application turned her down before the tenth person agreed, and she was faced with having to come up with a $300,000 bank loan to pay for it. It took her two years before she got the money, and her membership was approved. 
 
In 1969, Siebert founded Muriel Siebert & Company, becoming the first woman to own and run a brokerage firm that was a member of the NYSE. She later became the first woman superintendent of banking for the state of New York. 
 
Muriel Siebert died of cancer on Aug. 24, 2013, at age 84. Muriel Siebert & Company continues to operate today from offices in the New York Financial District. 
 
Greg Mathieson/Mai/Getty Images

TERM OF THE DAY, via @Investopedia $STUDY  
 
Modern Portfolio Theory 
Modern portfolio theory is a practical method for selecting investments in order to maximize their overall returns within an acceptable level of risk. This mathematical framework is used to build a portfolio of investments that maximizes the amount of expected return for a given level of risk. 
  
American economist Harry Markowitz pioneered this theory in his paper "Portfolio Selection," published in the Journal of Finance 70 years ago this year, in 1952. He was later awarded a Nobel Prize for his work on modern portfolio theory. The Nobel Prize was established 127 years ago today, on 27 November 1895. 
  
A key component of modern portfolio theory is diversification. Most investments are either high risk and high return, or low risk and low return. Markowitz argued that investors could achieve their best results by choosing an optimal mix of the two based on an assessment of their individual tolerance to risk.

TODAY IN HISTORY, via @Investopedia  
November 7, 2013 
  
On this day in 2013, Twitter began publicly trading on the New York Stock Exchange ($TWTR.P:NYSE).  
  
Shares opened at $45.10, 73% above the initial public offering (IPO) price of $26. They went as high as $50.09 before closing at $44.90. 
  
By the end of the year, shares had risen as high as $69, but then began to tumble, and within three years they had fallen to about $14. The stock started to rally in 2017, and hit an all-time high of more than $70 in February 2021.  
  
Shares took another downturn at the end of 2021, but they jumped again in April 2022 when billionaire and Tesla CEO Elon Musk announced he was buying the social media firm for $44 billion, or $54.20 per share. After several months of uncertainty over whether Musk would go through with the deal, he eventually gained control last month, taking Twitter private. Its final closing price was $53.70.  
 
Source: CNN Business 
Lars Niki / Getty Images

TODAY IN HISTORY, via @Investopedia 
November 6, 1893 
  
It was on this day in 1893 that Henry Ford became chief engineer at Thomas Edison’s Edison Illuminating Company of Detroit. Edison was a longtime mentor and friend to Henry Ford, and it wasn’t until six years later in 1899 that Ford resigned from the Edison Illuminating Company to found the Detroit Automobile Company.  
  
The Detroit Automobile Company would declare bankruptcy just 18 months after it was founded, but Ford didn’t give up. In 1903, Ford and 12 others invested $28,000 to found Ford Motor Company.  
  
Today, Ford ($F) is a leader in the global automotive industry, with a market capitalization of over $54 billion. 
 
Source: Ford Motor Company 
Getty Images

TODAY IN HISTORY, via @Investopedia $GM  
November 3, 1911 
  
On this day in 1911, the Chevrolet Motor Company was incorporated in Detroit by General Motors founder William “Billy” Durant, along with Swiss race car driver Louis Chevrolet. Durant thought Chevrolet’s fame would help sell cars, so he gave the firm Chevrolet’s name. 
  
Durant recognized the demand for lower-priced vehicles, and he wanted to produce a car that could compete with Ford’s Model T. The first Chryslers, called the Classic Six, were unveiled in 1913. That year, Durant moved Chrysler to Flint, Mich., and sales boomed. 
  
Eventually, Durant bought enough stock in General Motors to return as president, and in 1918, the carmaker bought Chevrolet and incorporated it into the GM brand, where it remains today. 
 
Source: Chevrolet Brothers 
William Durant 
Durant Foundation

TODAY IN HISTORY, via @Investopedia $STUDY  
October 30, 1929 
  
On this day in 1929, the Dow Jones Industrial Average had one of its best days ever, rocketing up 29.4 points, or 12.3%, to 258.47 as John D. Rockefeller Sr. announced: "There is nothing in the business situation to warrant the destruction of values that has taken place on the exchanges during the past week [so] my son and I have for some days been purchasing sound common stocks." The Dow went on to lose 84.1% more of its value before bottoming out on July 8, 1932 during the height of The Great Depression.  
 
Hulton Archive / Stringer / Getty Images

TODAY IN HISTORY, via @Investopedia $STUDY  
October 29, 1929 
  
This day in 1929 was called “Black Tuesday” on Wall Street, as the U.S. stock market crashed in one of the worst drops in history, and led the global economy into the Great Depression. 
  
The Dow lost 12% as many of those who bought stocks during the runup of the “Roaring Twenties” saw their investments wiped out. A large number of investors obtained shares on margin and were ruined financially when the selling left them without enough money to cover their stock purchases. 
  
The decline continued for several years, with the Dow hitting a 20th Century low of 41.22 on July 8, 1932. That was a drop of 89% from its earlier high of 381.17 attained less than two months before Black Tuesday. 
 
Hutton Archive / Contributor / Getty Images

October 25, 2000 
  
On this day in 2000, AT&T ($T) announced it was breaking up the business, ending 123 years of being a telecom firm that provided “all things to all people.”

TODAY IN HISTORY, via @Investopedia $STUDY  
October 24, 1929 
  
Today in 1929 is known in the financial world as Black Thursday, when the stock market plunged and began what is generally considered the start of the Stock Market Crash of 1929 that led to the Great Depression.  
  
During the “go-go” 1920s, investors poured money into stocks, creating at the time the longest bull market run in history. From August 1921 until September 1929, the Dow had soared six-fold, from 63 to 381.  
 
However, concerns about the gains led to gyrations in the market, especially with so many investors buying equities on margin. When trading opened on Oct. 24, the Dow plunged 11%, and a panic set in as those who purchased stocks with little money down had to dump shares to cover their losses. The selling continued throughout the day, with the average closing down 21% from the highs set the month before.   
 
Icon Communications / Getty Images

TODAY IN HISTORY, via @Investopedia 
October 19, 1987 
 
This day in 1987 was known as “Black Monday” on Wall Street as the Dow crashed 26.2%, its largest daily percentage drop in history. 
  
It’s believed the massive selloff was caused by a number of factors, including concerns about geopolitical events, the advent of computerized trading, and the effects of portfolio insurance. 
  
At the time, U.S. equities were in the fifth year of a bull market, and it was anticipated that a correction was likely coming. However, once the selling started that Monday, it soon intensified, sending the market spiraling downward. The crash caused a ripple effect throughout the world, with other major stock markets sinking as well.   
  
It took only two sessions for the Dow to recover more than half of its losses that day, although it would be almost two years before the average returned to pre-Black Monday levels.  
 
New York Times

Someone asked me if the small premium I pocketed is worth the $3 risk. My answer: $STUDY  
 
You're assessing it wrong. The $3 max possible loss is not the risk. Multiply it by the probability I get stuck with the share price above $85.39. (I took 39¢ in premium.) Call that, I dunno, 8% (once in 12½ trials). 8% of $3 is 24¢. That's the risk. But also, I could accept execution and go short if we're above 85 on expiration day. In such a scenario, if the likelihood that COIN would go back below 85.39 while I held on to the short is over 50%, I would decrease my risk further. 
 
If you get into a car, you could die in a crash. Yet you blithely drive down the block to the store to buy some briquettes and a six-pack of beer. Is that small joy worth risking your life? 
 
Risk is a complex calculus. (The chance of dying in a car crash is 2-3% over a lifetime.)

TODAY IN HISTORY, via @Investopedia 
September 16, 1908 
 
On this day in 1908, William Durant incorporated General Motors ($GM) as a holding company for the Buick Motor Company. 
  
Durant had been a successful producer of horse-drawn carriages before getting into the automobile business. Within two years, he brought in some of the biggest carmakers of that time, including Oldsmobile, Cadillac, Oakland (later named Pontiac), and the predecessors of GMC Truck. 
  
Debt from acquisitions led to his loss of control of the company in 1910. Durant left GM and founded the Chevrolet Motor Company in 1911. He returned in 1916, bringing Chevrolet with him. 
  
GM held the title of world’s biggest automaker for decades, but it was in danger of collapse during the 2007-2008 financial crisis. It declared bankruptcy in June 2009 and received a government bailout. GM quickly emerged from bankruptcy; today it remains one of the largest car producers. 
  
Source: Detroit Historical Society 
Bettmann

September 15, 2008 
  
This day in 2008 marked the seminal moment in the 2007-2008 financial crisis. Iconic investment bank Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy, overwhelmed by debt after the housing bubble burst. It was the biggest bankruptcy in history. 
  
At the time, Lehman was the fourth-largest investment bank in the U.S., with $619 billion in assets. However, the value of its holdings in mortgage-backed securities (MBS) tumbled along with the subprime mortgage market, putting the company in danger of collapse. 
  
Calls for a government bailout of the bank were rejected, but soon the demise of Lehman began a cascading crisis in the financial sector that threatened a global economic meltdown. A few weeks later, Congress passed the $700 billion Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP) to support the industry.

TODAY IN HISTORY, via @Investopedia  
August 28, 1937 
  
On this day in 1937, Risaburo Toyoda and Kiichiro Toyoda established Toyota Motor Co. Ltd., with initial capital of 12 million yen, to design and produce automobiles. The Toyodas, who ran a family-owned business producing spinning and weaving equipment, spent nearly a decade of their "spare time" making prototypes of compact, affordable cars in the hopes that they would appeal to Japan's working class. Their hard work eventually paid off, and Toyota became an international success. Toyota reported $27.2 trillion yen in global revenue in 2021, or about $245 billion¹. About 90% of Toyota's revenue comes from automotive sales.  
 
[¹For comparison, Tesla annual revenue for 2021 was $53.8 billion. That's about 22% of Toyota's. $TM $TSLA] 
  
Source: Toyota

TODAY IN HISTORY, via @Investopedia  
August 19, 2004 
  
On this day in 2004, Google made its much-anticipated debut as a publicly-traded company. [Enterprise value today: $1.57 trillion. And, today, old enough to vote.] 
  
The stock was priced in its initial public offering (IPO) at $85, with shares sold through a Dutch Auction. However, when trading began on the Nasdaq just before noon, the shares immediately hit $100. The price slipped to $95.96, but then recovered, rising as high as $104.06 before ending the day up 18% at $100.34. Some 22 million shares were traded, more than the 19.6 million sold in the IPO.   
  
Google shares fell to their all-time lows less than a month later, but have steadily climbed since then. Now trading as Alphabet ($GOOGL), the stock is priced more than 5,000% higher than it was on its opening day.   
  
Source: Wall Street Journal
